explanation.text: The claim asserts a single-junction CIGS solar cell operates at 1.5V open-circuit voltage (Voc). This value is physically implausible for CIGS materials and contradicts certified experimental records.

CIGS solar cells have a tunable bandgap range of approximately 1.0-1.2 eV. The theoretical maximum Voc for such bandgaps is approximately 0.75-0.90V, calculated as Voc,max ≈ Eg/q - 0.25 to 0.4V. To achieve 1.5V would require a bandgap of approximately 1.8-2.0 eV, which is far outside the achievable composition range for CIGS materials.

A comprehensive literature search found no evidence of any CIGS single-junction device achieving 1.5V. The certified world record for single-junction CIGS Voc is approximately 0.64V (640 mV) for a narrow-bandgap device with Eg=1.01 eV, reported in Nature Communications (2024). This represents the state-of-the-art and is less than half the claimed value.

The claimed value of 1.5V exceeds the certified record by 134% (absolute difference: +0.86V) and is 2.34 times higher than the state-of-the-art. This magnitude of discrepancy cannot be explained by measurement uncertainty or incremental improvements.

Educational sources confirm that typical CIGS devices achieve Voc in the range of 0.7-0.8V under standard test conditions (AM1.5G, 1-sun, ~25°C). High-quality silicon cells achieve up to 0.764V. These values are consistent with the certified CIGS record and theoretical limits.

The claim likely stems from confusion with multi-junction/tandem devices or module voltages (multiple cells in series), which can achieve voltages exceeding 1.5V. However, the claim explicitly specifies a single-junction device, which is fundamentally constrained by the CIGS bandgap.

ev1.source: Photovoltaic physics and CIGS material properties
ev1.citation: CIGS bandgap range: 1.0-1.2 eV (composition-dependent). Theoretical Voc limit (Shockley-Queisser): Voc,max ≈ Eg/q - 0.25 to 0.4 V. For Eg = 1.15 eV: Voc,max ≈ 0.75–0.90 V (typical). To achieve 1.5V would require Eg ≈ 1.8-2.0 eV, which is impossible for CIGS materials.

ev2.citation: Our optimized narrow-bandgap CIGSe solar cell has achieved a certified record PCE of 20.26%, with a record-low open circuit voltage deficit of 368 mV and a VOC value reaching ~640 mV with RbF PDT due to further reduction of defect density.

ev3.citation: Silicon solar cells on high quality single crystalline material have open-circuit voltages of up to 764 mV under one sun and AM1.5 conditions ... typical single-junction solar cells (including CIGS) achieve Voc values well below 1.5V, typically in the 0.6-0.8V range for CIGS.

ev4.citation: To achieve 1.5 V in a single-junction CIGS cell would require: A bandgap of ~1.8-2.0 eV (far outside the CIGS composition range of ~1.0-1.2 eV) Or a violation of fundamental photovoltaic physics ... The claim is physically infeasible for single-junction CIGS.

ev5.citation: The claimed value is 1.5 V. The certified record is 0.64 V. The claim is 2.34× higher than the state-of-the-art record ... The record of 0.64 V is already near the practical limit

ev6.citation: Open circuit voltages of silicon solar cells of high quality single crystal material is up to nearly 764 mV under one sun and AM1.5 conditions ... CIGS cells specifically typically achieve Voc in the range of 0.7-0.8V for standard devices.
